sentence.text: Drug Label for drug brand Triamterene and Hydrochlorothiazide, containing Triamterene and Hydrochlorothiazide.

mmtx.phraseText: Drug Label for drug brand Triamterene
Drug Label for drug brand Triamterene

sentence.text: Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should not be used in the presence of elevated serum potassium levels (greater than or equal to 5.5 mEq/liter).

mmtx.phraseText: used in the presence of elevated serum potassium levels

sentence.text: Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should not be given to patients receiving other potassium-conserving agents such as spironolactone, amiloride hydrochloride or other formulations containing triamterene.
Concomitant potassium supplementation in the form of medication, potassium-containing salt substitute or potassium-enriched diets should also not be used.

entity.text: potassium supplementation in the form of medication

mmtx.phraseText: Concomitant potassium supplementation in the form of medication,
Concomitant potassium supplementation in the form of medication,

ellipsisSentence.text: Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should not be given to patients receiving other potassium-conserving agents such as spironolactone, amiloride hydrochloride or other formulations containing triamterene.

sentence.text: Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide is contraindicated in patients with anuria, acute and chronic renal insufficiency or significant renal impairment.
Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should not be used in patients who are hypersensitive to triamterene or hydrochlorothiazide or other sulfonamide-derived drugs.
Abnormal elevation of serum potassium levels (greater than or equal to 5.5 mEq/liter) can occur with all potassium-conserving diuretic combinations, including triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide.

mmtx.phraseText: Abnormal elevation of serum potassium levels

sentence.text: Since uncorrected hyperkalemia may be fatal, serum potassium levels must be monitored at frequent intervals especially in patients first receiving triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide, when dosages are changed or with any illness that may influence renal function.
If hyperkalemia is present, triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be discontinued immediately and a thiazide alone should be substituted.
If the serum potassium exceeds 6.5 mEq/liter, more vigorous therapy is required.
These include the intravenous administration of calcium chloride solution, sodium bicarbonate solution and/or the oral or parenteral administration of glucose with a rapid-acting insulin preparation.

mmtx.phraseText: the intravenous administration of calcium chloride solution,

sentence.text: The renal clearances of hydrochlorothiazide and the pharmacologically active metabolite of triamterene, the sulfate ester of hydroxytriamterene, have been shown to be reduced and the plasma levels increased following triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide administration to elderly patients and patients with impaired renal function.

mmtx.phraseText: the pharmacologically active metabolite of triamterene,

sentence.text: Hyperkalemia has been reported in diabetic patients with the use of potassium-conserving agents even in the absence of apparent renal impairment.

mmtx.phraseText: agents even in the absence of apparent renal impairment.

sentence.text: Accordingly, triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be avoided in diabetic patients.

Because of the potassium-sparing properties of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be used cautiously, if at all, with these agents (see PRECAUTIONS: Drug Interactions).
If triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide is employed, frequent evaluations of acid/base balance and serum electrolytes are necessary.
Hydrochlorothiazide, a sulfonamide, can cause an idiosyncratic reaction, resulting in acute transient myopia and acute angle-closure glaucoma.
Patients receiving triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be carefully monitored for fluid or electrolyte imbalances, i.e., hyponatremia, hypochloremic alkalosis, hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.
Determination of serum electrolytes to detect possible electrolyte imbalance should be performed at appropriate intervals.

Hypokalemia may develop with thiazide therapy, especially with brisk diuresis, when severe cirrhosis is present, or during concomitant use of corticosteroids, ACTH, amphotericin B or after prolonged thiazide therapy.

mmtx.phraseText: or during concomitant use of corticosteroids,

sentence.text: However, hypokalemia of this type is usually prevented by the triamterene component of triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide.

mmtx.phraseText: prevented by the triamterene component of triamterene
prevented by the triamterene component of triamterene

sentence.text: Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide may produce an elevated blood urea nitrogen level (BUN), creatinine level or both.

mmtx.phraseText: an elevated blood urea nitrogen level (BUN),

sentence.text: Elevations in BUN and creatinine levels may be more frequent in patients receiving divided dose diuretic therapy.
If azotemia increases, triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be discontinued.

Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be used with caution in patients with impaired hepatic function or progressive liver disease, since minor alterations of fluid and electrolyte balance may precipitate hepatic coma.
Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be used with caution in patients with histories of renal lithiasis.
Triamterene is a weak folic acid antagonist and may contribute to the appearance of megaloblastosis in instances where folic acid stores are decreased.

mmtx.phraseText: in instances where folic acid stores

sentence.text: Calcium excretion is decreased by thiazides.
Thiazides may add to or potentiate the action of other antihypertensive drugs.

entity.text: add to or potentiate the action

mmtx.phraseText: the action of other antihypertensive drugs.

sentence.text: The thiazides may decrease arterial responsiveness to norepinephrine.
Thiazides have also been shown to increase the responsiveness to tubocurarine.
Lithium generally should not be given with diuretics because they reduce its renal clearance and add a high risk of lithium toxicity.

mmtx.phraseText: a high risk of lithium toxicity.

sentence.text: Acute renal failure has been reported in a few patients receiving indomethacin and formulations containing triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide.
Caution is therefore advised when administering non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents with triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide.
Potassium-sparing agents should be used very cautiously, if at all, in conjunction with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors due to a greatly increased risk of hyperkalemia.

mmtx.phraseText: in conjunction with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors

sentence.text: Serum potassium should be monitored frequently.

ellipsisSentence.text: Potassium-sparing agents should be used very cautiously, if at all, in conjunction with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors due to a greatly increased risk of hyperkalemia.
Potassium-sparing agents should be used very cautiously, if at all, in conjunction with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors due to a greatly increased risk of hyperkalemia.

sentence.text: Triamterene and quinidine have similar fluorescence spectra, thus triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide may interfere with the measurement of quinidine.

mmtx.phraseText: interfere with the measurement of quinidine.

sentence.text: Long term studies with triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide have not been conducted.

On a body-weight basis, these doses are 600 times (in mice) and 100 times (in rats) the Maximum Recommended Human Dose (MRHD) for hydrochlorothiazide (50 mg/day or 1 mg/kg/day based on a 50 kg patient).
Studies of the mutagenic potential of triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide have not been performed.

mmtx.phraseText: Studies of the mutagenic potential of triamterene

sentence.text: Studies of the effects of triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide or of triamterene alone on animal reproductive function have not been conducted.

mmtx.phraseText: Studies of the effects of triamterene

sentence.text: Triamterene and Hydrochlorothiazide
Animal reproduction studies to determine the potential for fetal harm by triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide have not been conducted.
Nevertheless, a One Generation Study in the rat approximated triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide's composition by using a 1:1 ratio of triamterene to hydrochlorothiazide (30:30 mg/kg/day).

mmtx.phraseText: a One Generation Study in the rat approximated triamterene

sentence.text: The safe use of triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide in pregnancy has not been established since there are no adequate and well-controlled studies with triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide in pregnant women.
Triamterene and hydrochlorothiazide should be used during pregnancy only if the potential benefit justifies the risk to the fetus.
Thiazides and triamterene have been shown to cross the placental barrier and appear in cord blood.
The use of thiazides and triamterene in pregnant women requires that the anticipated benefits be weighed against possible hazards to the fetus.
Thiazides and triamterene in combination have not been studied in nursing mothers.
Thiazides are excreted in human breast milk.
If use of the combination drug product is deemed essential, the patient should stop nursing.

mmtx.phraseText: use of the combination drug product
use of the combination drug product
